docs.lead_paragraph: American household incomes lost ground last year as the poverty rate remained flat, a sign the U.S. economic expansion had yet to lead to gains for many Americans five years after the 2007-2009 recession.

docs.lead_paragraph: CVS Health Corp reached a $48 million settlement of a lawsuit accusing the U.S. drugstore operator of fraudulently concealing a big loss of revenue in its pharmacy benefits manager business, culminating in a plunge in its stock price.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a gay man, the Boston attorney thought he was doing the responsible thing when he asked his doctor to prescribe Truvada, a drug hailed as a way to halt the spread of AIDS. But when he tried to get long-term care insurance, Mutual of Omaha turned him down, saying it does not offer coverage to anyone who takes the drug.

docs.lead_paragraph: People seeking refugee status in European countries are generally entitled to food, or money to buy it, plus shelter and medical attention, schooling for their children and access to interpreters and lawyers.

headline.print_headline: Factbox: Benefits Offered to Asylum Seekers in European Countries

docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has reached a settlement with the North Broward Hospital District, which was accused of having improper financial ties with doctors who referred patients to the district.

headline.main: Florida Hospital District to Pay $69.5 Million to Settle Lawsuit
headline.print_headline: Florida Hospital District to Pay $69.5. Million to Settle Lawsuit

docs.abstract: Justice Department and North Broward Hospital District, South Florida, reach $69.5 million settlement in lawsuit alleging illegal financial relationships between referring doctors and district facilities; Dr Michael Reilly, who initiated suit, will receive more than $12 million.
docs.snippet: The Justice Department has reached a settlement with the North Broward Hospital District, which was accused of having improper financial ties with doctors who referred patients to the district.

docs.lead_paragraph: The federal marketplace was intended to increase competition, partly by creating consumer-led co-ops. But many new entrants have struggled, and several have folded.
docs.abstract: Marketplace is proving to be unfriendly to new health insurance co-ops trying to launch in industry controlled by powerful businesses; federal government will attempt to help them prosper, but some insurance experts think co-op failures around the country will continue.
docs.snippet: The federal marketplace was intended to increase competition, partly by creating consumer-led co-ops. But many new entrants have struggled, and several have folded.

docs.lead_paragraph: The courts are trying to figure out whether Uber’s drivers are contractors or employers from a standard rooted in 19th-century labor law.

headline.main: Uber Case Highlights Outdated Worker Protection Laws
headline.print_headline: Uber Case Highlights Outdated Worker Protection Laws

docs.abstract: Steven Davidoff Solomon Deal Professor column notes that litigation over whether Uber's drivers in California are employees or contractors highlights outdated worker protection laws.
docs.snippet: The courts are trying to figure out whether Uber’s drivers are contractors or employers from a standard rooted in 19th-century labor law.

docs.lead_paragraph: What is condemned during a campaign is often tolerated as soon as a new president settles into the Oval Office.

headline.main: Republicans Vow to Erase Obama’s Record, but Such Promises Are Rarely Kept
headline.print_headline: A President’s Legacy of Actions Is Too Impactful to Merely Erase

docs.abstract: Political memo; Republican presidential candidates are promising to erase and take back Pres Obama's legacy of actions, but history shows campaign promises sometimes fade when confronted with reality of being president.
docs.snippet: What is condemned during a campaign is often tolerated as soon as a new president settles into the Oval Office.
